content.title: Hemophilia B (Christmas Disease)
content.summary: Hemophilia B (Christmas disease) is an X-linked recessive bleeding disorder caused by deficiency of coagulation factor IX (FIX). Named after Stephen Christmas, the first patient described with this condition, it accounts for ~15-20% of hemophilia cases. Clinical manifestations are indistinguishable from hemophilia A: spontaneous hemarthroses, deep muscle hematomas, and prolonged bleeding after surgery or trauma. Severity correlates with FIX activity levels. Treatment involves FIX replacement therapy, with newer extended half-life products and gene therapy offering improved options.
key_points: X-linked recessive; FIX deficiency; 15-20% of hemophilia cases
Clinically identical to hemophilia A - hemarthroses, muscle bleeds, surgical bleeding
Severity: Severe (<1% FIX), Moderate (1-5% FIX), Mild (5-40% FIX)
Labs: Prolonged PTT, normal PT, normal platelet count, low FIX activity
Treatment: FIX concentrate (plasma-derived or recombinant); extended half-life products available
Gene therapy (etranacogene dezaparvovec) now FDA-approved for hemophilia B
content.statement: Hemophilia B is an X-linked recessive bleeding disorder caused by factor IX deficiency, presenting with hemarthroses, muscle bleeds, and prolonged bleeding, diagnosed by prolonged PTT and low FIX activity, and managed with FIX replacement therapy or gene therapy.

explanation.intuition: Factor IX is essential for the intrinsic pathway of coagulation. Without it, the clotting cascade cannot proceed efficiently, leading to bleeding especially into joints and muscles. Think of it as a missing link in a chain reaction - the chain breaks down at that point.
explanation.key_insight: Hemophilia B is clinically indistinguishable from hemophilia A - you cannot tell them apart by symptoms. The only way to differentiate is by measuring specific factor levels (FVIII vs FIX). This is critical for treatment selection.
explanation.technical_details: FIX is a vitamin K-dependent serine protease synthesized in the liver. It is activated by FXIa in the intrinsic pathway or by the tissue factor-FVIIa complex. Activated FIX (FIXa) forms the tenase complex with FVIIIa on phospholipid surfaces to activate FX. FIX gene (F9) is located on Xq27.1; mutations include point mutations, deletions, and insertions. Half-life of FIX is ~18-24 hours (longer than FVIII).

definitions_glossary.hemophilia_b: X-linked recessive bleeding disorder caused by factor IX deficiency
definitions_glossary.christmas_disease: Eponymous name for hemophilia B after Stephen Christmas, the first described patient
definitions_glossary.factor_ix: Vitamin K-dependent coagulation factor essential for intrinsic pathway; FIX
definitions_glossary.hemarthrosis: Bleeding into a joint space; hallmark of severe hemophilia
definitions_glossary.tenase_complex: FIXa-FVIIIa complex that activates factor X
definitions_glossary.intrinsic_pathway: Coagulation pathway initiated by contact activation; measured by PTT
definitions_glossary.extended_half_life_products: FIX concentrates engineered for longer circulation time
definitions_glossary.gene_therapy: Treatment delivering functional FIX gene via viral vector
definitions_glossary.inhibitor: Alloantibody against infused FIX that neutralizes replacement therapy
definitions_glossary.prophylaxis: Regular factor replacement to prevent bleeding episodes
definitions_glossary.on_demand_treatment: Factor replacement given only when bleeding occurs
definitions_glossary.target_joint: Joint with recurrent hemarthroses leading to chronic damage

genetic_basis.inheritance: X-linked recessive; F9 gene on chromosome Xq27.1
genetic_basis.female_carriers: Usually asymptomatic but may have mild bleeding if FIX <40%
genetic_basis.de_novo_mutations: ~30% of cases have no family history

coagulation_defect.role_of_FIX: Activated FIX forms tenase complex with FVIIIa to activate FX
coagulation_defect.intrinsic_pathway: FIX deficiency impairs intrinsic pathway amplification
coagulation_defect.result: Insufficient thrombin generation; unstable fibrin clot

severe_hemophilia.onset: Infancy/early childhood; may present at circumcision

moderate_hemophilia.manifestations: Bleeding with minor trauma; occasional spontaneous bleeds

mild_hemophilia.manifestations: Bleeding only with significant trauma or surgery; may be diagnosed in adulthood

diagnostic_criteria.confirmatory_test: Factor IX activity assay - low or absent
diagnostic_criteria.mixing_study: PTT corrects with normal plasma mixing (unless inhibitor present)
diagnostic_criteria.inhibitor_screen: Bethesda assay if factor replacement ineffective
diagnostic_criteria.genetic_testing: F9 gene sequencing for carrier detection and prenatal diagnosis

differential_diagnosis: Factor XI deficiency - mild bleeding, Ashkenazi Jewish predilection
von Willebrand disease - mucocutaneous bleeding pattern
Vitamin K deficiency - affects II, VII, IX, X; prolonged PT and PTT
Liver disease coagulopathy - multiple factor deficiencies

acute_bleeding.goal: Raise FIX to appropriate level based on bleed severity
acute_bleeding.dosing: FIX dose (IU) = Weight (kg) × Desired FIX rise (%) × 1.0

factor_products.plasma_derived: Contains FIX purified from human plasma
factor_products.dosing_interval: Standard: twice weekly; EHL: every 1-2 weeks

gene_therapy.mechanism: AAV5 vector delivers functional F9 gene to liver
gene_therapy.efficacy: Sustained FIX expression; most patients off prophylaxis

inhibitor_management.incidence: ~3-5% in hemophilia B (lower than hemophilia A)
inhibitor_management.allergy_risk: FIX inhibitors associated with anaphylaxis to FIX products

prophylaxis.indication: Severe hemophilia; history of recurrent bleeds
prophylaxis.benefit: Prevents joint damage; improves quality of life

definition.@value: X-linked recessive bleeding disorder caused by deficiency of coagulation factor IX, characterized by hemarthroses, muscle hematomas, and prolonged bleeding

scopeNote.@value: Second most common hemophilia; clinically indistinguishable from hemophilia A

learning_objectives: Differentiate hemophilia B from hemophilia A based on factor levels
Interpret coagulation studies in suspected hemophilia
Calculate FIX dosing for acute bleeding episodes
Explain the role of gene therapy in hemophilia B management
clinical_pearls: Cannot distinguish hemophilia A from B clinically - must measure factor levels
FIX has longer half-life (~24h) than FVIII (~12h) - less frequent dosing
Hemophilia B has lower inhibitor rate (~3-5%) but higher anaphylaxis risk with inhibitors
Hemgenix (gene therapy) FDA-approved 2022 - can achieve sustained FIX expression
Dosing: FIX dose = Weight × Desired rise × 1.0 (vs ×0.5 for FVIII)
common_misconceptions: Hemophilia B is clinically different from A - they are indistinguishable
All hemophilia patients bleed spontaneously - only severe (<1%) patients do
Hemophilia only affects males - female carriers can have mild bleeding
